canonical_explanation.text: Equilibrium is the state in which the rates of the forward and reverse processes become equal, and the macroscopic properties of the system remain constant with time. Physical equilibria (e.g., liquid–vapour, solid–liquid) and chemical equilibria are both dynamic — processes continue at the molecular level even though no net change is observed. The law of mass action states that the rate of a reaction is proportional to the product of the active masses (concentrations) of the reactants, each raised to the power of its stoichiometric coefficient. For a general reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD, the equilibrium constant Kc = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b. When expressed in terms of partial pressures, Kp = (pC)^c(pD)^d / (pA)^a(pB)^b, and the relation Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn holds, where Δn = (c + d) − (a + b) for gaseous species. Le Chatelier's principle states that if a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts in the direction that tends to counteract the disturbance. Changes in concentration, pressure, and temperature all affect the equilibrium position. Ionic equilibrium involves the equilibrium established by weak electrolytes in aqueous solution. Arrhenius defined acids as H⁺ donors and bases as OH⁻ donors in water; Brønsted–Lowry defined acids as proton donors and bases as proton acceptors; Lewis defined acids as electron-pair acceptors and bases as electron-pair donors. The ionic product of water Kw = [H⁺][OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25 °C. pH = −log[H⁺]; for acids Ka = [H⁺][A⁻]/[HA], and for bases Kb = [BH⁺][OH⁻]/[B]. The relation Ka × Kb = Kw holds for a conjugate acid–base pair. Buffer solutions resist changes in pH upon addition of small amounts of acid or base. The Henderson–Hasselbalch equation is pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]). Solubility equilibrium involves sparingly soluble salts; the solubility product Ksp = product of the ion concentrations raised to their stoichiometric powers. Precipitation occurs when the ionic product Q > Ksp; the common ion effect decreases the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt.
rules: At equilibrium, the rate of forward reaction equals the rate of reverse reaction; concentrations remain constant.
Kc = [products]^coefficients / [reactants]^coefficients; pure solids and liquids are excluded from the expression.
Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn, where Δn = moles of gaseous products − moles of gaseous reactants.
Le Chatelier's principle: a system at equilibrium shifts to counteract any imposed change (concentration, pressure, temperature).
Increasing temperature shifts equilibrium in the endothermic direction; a catalyst does not shift equilibrium.
Arrhenius: acid gives H⁺, base gives OH⁻. Brønsted–Lowry: acid donates proton, base accepts proton. Lewis: acid accepts electron pair, base donates electron pair.
Ka × Kb = Kw for a conjugate acid–base pair.
Henderson–Hasselbalch: pH = pKa + log([salt]/[acid]) for acidic buffers.
Ksp = product of ion concentrations at equilibrium; precipitation occurs when ionic product > Ksp.

questions.question_text: Chemical equilibrium is described as 'dynamic' because:

options.text: The concentrations of reactants and products keep changing
Both forward and reverse reactions continue to occur at equal rates
The system is not in a stable state

questions.explanation_correct: At dynamic equilibrium, both the forward and reverse reactions continue to occur, but their rates are equal, so there is no net change in concentrations. The system appears static macroscopically but is active at the molecular level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concentrations do not keep changing — they remain constant at equilibrium. The system is stable (in terms of macroscopic properties). Temperature does not fluctuate at equilibrium.

questions.question_text: For the equilibrium reaction aA + bB ⇌ cC + dD, the expression for Kc is:
questions.explanation_correct: By the law of mass action, Kc = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b, with products in the numerator and reactants in the denominator, each raised to its stoichiometric coefficient.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has reactants in the numerator (inverse of Kc). Option C ignores stoichiometric coefficients. Option D is a ratio of coefficients, not concentrations.

questions.question_text: In the equilibrium expression, the concentrations of pure solids and pure liquids:

options.text: Are included with their stoichiometric coefficients
Are not included because their activities are unity

questions.explanation_correct: Pure solids and pure liquids have fixed concentrations (densities) that do not change during the reaction. Their activities are taken as 1 by convention and are therefore excluded from the equilibrium expression.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pure solids and liquids are not included anywhere in the Kc or Kp expression. Their concentrations are constant and absorbed into the equilibrium constant.

questions.question_text: For the reaction CaCO₃(s) ⇌ CaO(s) + CO₂(g), the equilibrium expression is:
questions.explanation_correct: CaCO₃ and CaO are pure solids, so their activities are 1 and they are excluded from the expression. The only gaseous species is CO₂, so Kp = p(CO₂).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A and D include pure solids in the expression, which is incorrect. Option C inverts the expression.

questions.question_text: If the equilibrium constant for A ⇌ B is K, then the equilibrium constant for 2B ⇌ 2A is:
questions.explanation_correct: Reversing a reaction inverts K (gives 1/K). Multiplying a reaction by a factor n raises K to the power n. Reversing A ⇌ B gives K' = 1/K for B ⇌ A. Multiplying by 2 gives K'' = (1/K)² = 1/K².
questions.explanation_incorrect: K² would apply if the forward reaction were multiplied by 2 (without reversing). 2K incorrectly multiplies rather than exponentiating. 1/(2K) confuses multiplication with exponentiation.

questions.question_text: The reaction quotient Q for a reaction is less than Kc. This means:

options.text: The reaction will shift towards reactants (reverse direction)
The reaction will shift towards products (forward direction)

questions.explanation_correct: When Q < Kc, the ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations is less than at equilibrium. The system must produce more products and consume more reactants to reach equilibrium, so the reaction shifts forward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Q = K indicates equilibrium. Q > K means the reaction shifts in reverse. The reaction has not reached completion; equilibrium is not the same as completion.

questions.question_text: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), if Kc = 0.5 at a certain temperature, then for ½N₂(g) + 3/2 H₂(g) ⇌ NH₃(g), Kc is:
questions.explanation_correct: The second reaction is the first reaction divided by 2. When a reaction is multiplied by a factor n, the new Kc = (old Kc)^n. Here n = 1/2, so Kc(new) = (0.5)^(1/2) = √0.5 ≈ 0.707.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0.25 is (0.5)². 1.0 is incorrect. 2.0 is 1/0.5, which would apply if the reaction were reversed.

questions.question_text: A large value of Kc (>>1) indicates that at equilibrium:

options.text: Reactants and products are present in equal amounts

questions.explanation_correct: A large Kc means the numerator (product concentrations) is much larger than the denominator (reactant concentrations). This indicates that at equilibrium, the reaction lies far to the right, with products predominating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reactants predominate when Kc << 1. Equal amounts correspond to Kc ≈ 1. A large Kc does not mean the reaction has not started.

questions.question_text: The relationship between Kp and Kc is:
questions.explanation_correct: The relation is Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn, where Δn = moles of gaseous products − moles of gaseous reactants, R is the gas constant, and T is absolute temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Addition and subtraction of RT are dimensionally incorrect for equilibrium constants. Division by (RT)^Δn inverts the correct relationship.

questions.question_text: According to Le Chatelier's principle, if the concentration of a reactant is increased at equilibrium, the equilibrium will:
questions.explanation_correct: Le Chatelier's principle states that the system will counteract the disturbance. Increasing a reactant concentration makes Q < K, so the equilibrium shifts forward (towards products) to consume the added reactant and re-establish equilibrium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shifting towards reactants would increase the disturbance. The equilibrium position changes, but not Kc (which depends only on temperature). It does not remain unchanged.

questions.question_text: A catalyst affects a chemical equilibrium by:

options.text: Helping the system reach equilibrium faster without changing Kc

questions.explanation_correct: A catalyst lowers the activation energy equally for both forward and reverse reactions, so equilibrium is reached faster but the equilibrium position (Kc) is unchanged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A catalyst does not shift equilibrium in either direction. It does not change the equilibrium constant, as it affects both forward and reverse rates equally.

questions.question_text: For the exothermic reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), increasing the temperature will:

options.text: Shift equilibrium to the right and increase Kc
Shift equilibrium to the left and decrease Kc
Shift equilibrium to the right and decrease Kc

questions.explanation_correct: For an exothermic reaction, heat is a product. Increasing temperature is equivalent to adding heat, which shifts equilibrium to the left (endothermic direction) to absorb the extra heat. This also decreases the value of Kc.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shifting right would occur for an endothermic reaction upon heating. Temperature does affect equilibrium (unlike a catalyst). Kc changes with temperature.

questions.question_text: For the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), what happens when the total pressure is increased at constant temperature?
questions.explanation_correct: Δn = 2 − (2 + 1) = −1. Increasing pressure favours the side with fewer moles of gas (products side). The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more SO₃.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shifting left would increase the number of gas moles, which opposes the pressure increase — not what Le Chatelier predicts. Kp is unchanged by pressure changes (it depends only on temperature).

questions.question_text: For the reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), an increase in total pressure at constant temperature will:

options.text: Have no effect on the equilibrium position

questions.explanation_correct: Δn = 2 − (1 + 1) = 0. When the number of moles of gas is the same on both sides, changing pressure has no effect on the equilibrium position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: With Δn = 0, neither direction is favoured by pressure changes. Kp is unaffected by pressure changes at constant temperature.

questions.question_text: For N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), Kc = 0.5 at a certain temperature. The value of Kp at the same temperature is: (R = 0.0821 L atm mol⁻¹ K⁻¹, T = 500 K)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A uses Δn = +2 instead of −2. Option C uses Δn = +1. Option D assumes Kp = Kc, which is only true when Δn = 0.

questions.question_text: In the Haber process for ammonia synthesis (N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, ΔH = −92 kJ), the conditions that favour maximum yield of NH₃ are:
questions.explanation_correct: The forward reaction is exothermic (ΔH < 0) and decreases the number of gas moles (Δn = −2). Low temperature favours the exothermic direction, and high pressure favours the side with fewer moles of gas. Both favour product formation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: High temperature shifts equilibrium backward (endothermic direction). Low pressure shifts equilibrium toward more gas moles (reactant side). The optimal conditions for yield are low T, high P (though practically, moderate T ~700 K is used with a catalyst for adequate rate).

questions.question_text: Adding an inert gas to an equilibrium mixture in a rigid container at constant temperature:
questions.explanation_correct: Adding an inert gas at constant volume increases the total pressure but does not change the partial pressures or concentrations of the reacting species. Therefore, Q remains equal to K and the equilibrium is unaffected.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Since concentrations are unchanged, there is no shift in either direction. Kc depends only on temperature, not on the presence of inert gases.

questions.question_text: Adding an inert gas to an equilibrium mixture at constant total pressure (by increasing volume) will shift the equilibrium for A(g) ⇌ 2B(g) towards:
questions.explanation_correct: At constant total pressure, adding inert gas increases the volume. This effectively decreases the partial pressures of reacting gases. The equilibrium shifts toward the side with more moles of gas (products, with 2 mol vs 1 mol) to counteract the decrease in pressure.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shifting left would reduce gas moles, not counteract the decreased partial pressures. The shift does occur because partial pressures change. The direction depends on Δn, not temperature.

questions.question_text: According to the Brønsted–Lowry theory, an acid is:

options.text: A substance that donates an electron pair
A substance that accepts a proton
A substance that donates a proton
A substance that releases OH⁻ ions in water

questions.explanation_correct: In the Brønsted–Lowry theory, an acid is a proton (H⁺) donor. For example, HCl donates a proton to water: HCl → H⁺ + Cl⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electron-pair donor is a Lewis base. A proton acceptor is a Brønsted–Lowry base. Releasing OH⁻ ions describes an Arrhenius base.

questions.question_text: A Lewis acid is defined as:

options.text: A substance that increases [H⁺] in water

questions.explanation_correct: A Lewis acid is a species that can accept an electron pair to form a coordinate covalent bond. Examples include BF₃, AlCl₃, and metal cations like Fe³⁺.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A proton donor is a Brønsted–Lowry acid. An electron pair donor is a Lewis base. Increasing [H⁺] describes an Arrhenius acid.

questions.question_text: The conjugate base of H₂O is:
questions.explanation_correct: The conjugate base of an acid is formed by removing one proton (H⁺). Removing H⁺ from H₂O gives OH⁻. Water acts as an acid when it donates a proton: H₂O → H⁺ + OH⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H₃O⁺ is the conjugate acid of water (formed when water accepts a proton). O²⁻ results from removing two protons, which is not a conjugate relationship. H₂O₂ is hydrogen peroxide, a different substance.

questions.question_text: Water can act as both an acid and a base. This property is called:
questions.explanation_correct: A substance that can act as both an acid (proton donor) and a base (proton acceptor) is called amphoteric (or amphiprotic). Water donates a proton to form OH⁻ (acting as acid) or accepts a proton to form H₃O⁺ (acting as base).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Neutralisation is the reaction between an acid and a base. Polyprotic refers to acids that can donate more than one proton. Buffering action involves resisting pH changes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a Lewis acid but NOT a Brønsted–Lowry acid?
questions.explanation_correct: BF₃ has an incomplete octet on boron and can accept an electron pair (Lewis acid), but it has no proton to donate, so it is not a Brønsted–Lowry acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: HCl, H₂SO₄, and CH₃COOH are all proton donors (Brønsted–Lowry acids) as well as Lewis acids. The question asks for one that is exclusively a Lewis acid.

questions.question_text: The ionic product of water (Kw) at 25 °C is:
questions.explanation_correct: Kw = [H⁺][OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25 °C. In pure water, [H⁺] = [OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻⁷ M, giving Kw = (10⁻⁷)(10⁻⁷) = 10⁻¹⁴.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.0 × 10⁻⁷ is the concentration of H⁺ (or OH⁻) in pure water, not Kw itself. 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁰ is incorrect. 1.0 × 10⁻⁷ M is a concentration, not the ionic product.

questions.question_text: Identify the conjugate acid–base pairs in: NH₃ + H₂O ⇌ NH₄⁺ + OH⁻
questions.explanation_correct: NH₃ (base) accepts a proton to form NH₄⁺ (its conjugate acid) — first pair: NH₃/NH₄⁺. H₂O (acid) donates a proton to form OH⁻ (its conjugate base) — second pair: H₂O/OH⁻.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conjugate pairs differ by exactly one proton. NH₃/OH⁻ and H₂O/NH₄⁺ are not correct conjugate pairs. The pairs must be from the same species gaining or losing a proton.

questions.question_text: The stronger the acid, its conjugate base is:
questions.explanation_correct: A strong acid has a high tendency to donate protons, meaning its conjugate base has very little tendency to accept protons — making it a weak base. For example, HCl is a strong acid and Cl⁻ is a very weak base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A strong acid does not produce a strong conjugate base — they are inversely related. The conjugate base is not neutral. Strength of an acid and its conjugate base are not equal.

questions.question_text: The pH of a solution with [H⁺] = 1.0 × 10⁻³ M is:
questions.explanation_correct: pH = −log[H⁺] = −log(1.0 × 10⁻³) = −(−3) = 3. A pH of 3 indicates an acidic solution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: pH 11 corresponds to [H⁺] = 10⁻¹¹. pH 7 is neutral. pH −3 is not obtained with this concentration (would require [H⁺] = 1000 M).

questions.question_text: The pH of a neutral solution at 25 °C is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a neutral solution at 25 °C, [H⁺] = [OH⁻] = 1.0 × 10⁻⁷ M. Therefore pH = −log(10⁻⁷) = 7.
questions.explanation_incorrect: pH 0 corresponds to [H⁺] = 1 M (strongly acidic). pH 14 corresponds to [OH⁻] = 1 M (strongly basic). pH 1 is acidic.

questions.question_text: For a weak acid HA, the dissociation constant Ka is given by:
questions.explanation_correct: For HA ⇌ H⁺ + A⁻, Ka = [H⁺][A⁻] / [HA]. This is the equilibrium constant for the dissociation of the weak acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is the inverse of Ka. Option C has HA in the numerator instead of the denominator. Option D omits [HA] from the denominator.

questions.question_text: The Ka of a weak acid is 1.0 × 10⁻⁵. Its pKa is:
questions.explanation_correct: pKa = −log Ka = −log(1.0 × 10⁻⁵) = 5. A higher pKa indicates a weaker acid.
questions.explanation_incorrect: −5 is log Ka, not −log Ka. 9 is incorrect. 10⁻⁵ is Ka itself, not pKa.

questions.question_text: The pH of a 0.01 M NaOH solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: [OH⁻] = 0.01 M = 10⁻² M. pOH = −log(10⁻²) = 2. pH = 14 − pOH = 14 − 2 = 12. The solution is basic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: pH 2 would mean the solution is acidic (confusing pH with pOH). pH 7 is neutral. pH 14 would require [OH⁻] = 1 M.

questions.question_text: A buffer solution of pH 5 can be prepared by mixing:

options.text: A strong acid and its salt
A weak acid (pKa ≈ 5) and its sodium salt
A strong acid and a strong base
A weak base and a strong base

questions.explanation_correct: An acidic buffer is prepared from a weak acid and its conjugate base (salt). By the Henderson–Hasselbalch equation, pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]). For pH = 5 with equal concentrations, pKa should be approximately 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Strong acids cannot form buffers (they dissociate completely). A strong acid + strong base gives a neutral salt, not a buffer. A weak base + strong base does not form a buffer system.

questions.question_text: For a conjugate acid–base pair, Ka × Kb equals:
questions.explanation_correct: For a conjugate acid–base pair, Ka × Kb = Kw = 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ at 25 °C. This fundamental relationship connects the strengths of a conjugate acid and its conjugate base.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ka × Kb = 1 is incorrect. 10⁻⁷ is the concentration of H⁺ in pure water, not the product Ka × Kb. 14 is pH + pOH, not Ka × Kb.

questions.question_text: The pH of a 0.1 M solution of a weak acid HA with Ka = 1.0 × 10⁻⁵ is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: pH 1 would correspond to a strong acid at 0.1 M. pH 5 is the pKa, not the pH. pH 7 is neutral, not acidic.

questions.question_text: A buffer solution contains 0.1 M CH₃COOH (pKa = 4.76) and 0.1 M CH₃COONa. The pH of the solution is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using Henderson–Hasselbalch: pH = pKa + log([A⁻]/[HA]) = 4.76 + log(0.1/0.1) = 4.76 + log(1) = 4.76 + 0 = 4.76. When [acid] = [salt], pH = pKa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: pH 7.00 is neutral, not a buffer with acetic acid. 9.24 is pKb (14 − 4.76). 2.88 would correspond to a much more acidic solution.

questions.question_text: If the Kb of NH₃ is 1.8 × 10⁻⁵, the Ka of NH₄⁺ is:
questions.explanation_correct: NH₄⁺ is the conjugate acid of NH₃. Ka × Kb = Kw → Ka = Kw / Kb = (1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴) / (1.8 × 10⁻⁵) = 5.6 × 10⁻¹⁰.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.8 × 10⁻⁵ is Kb of NH₃, not Ka of NH₄⁺. 1.0 × 10⁻¹⁴ is Kw. 5.6 × 10⁻⁵ has an incorrect exponent.

questions.question_text: The solubility product (Ksp) of a sparingly soluble salt is defined as:

options.text: The product of the concentrations of the undissolved salt
The product of the molar concentrations of the ions, each raised to the power of its coefficient, at equilibrium
The total concentration of all ions in solution
The ratio of dissolved salt to undissolved salt

questions.explanation_correct: For a salt MₓAᵧ ⇌ xM^(y+) + yA^(x−), Ksp = [M^(y+)]^x × [A^(x−)]^y. It is the equilibrium constant for the dissolution of the salt, with the solid excluded from the expression.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The undissolved solid is not included in Ksp. Total ion concentration is not the same as the product of ion concentrations. The ratio of dissolved to undissolved salt does not define Ksp.

questions.question_text: Precipitation of a sparingly soluble salt occurs when:
questions.explanation_correct: When the ionic product Q exceeds Ksp, the solution is supersaturated and the excess ions precipitate as the solid salt until Q decreases to Ksp (equilibrium is re-established).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Q < Ksp means the solution is unsaturated (no precipitation). Q = Ksp means the solution is saturated (equilibrium, no net precipitation). Q = 0 means no ions are present.

questions.question_text: The common ion effect refers to the decrease in solubility of a salt when:

options.text: An electrolyte with a common ion is added

questions.explanation_correct: The common ion effect is the suppression of dissociation of a weak electrolyte or the decrease in solubility of a sparingly soluble salt by the addition of a strong electrolyte having an ion in common. This is an application of Le Chatelier's principle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Temperature changes affect solubility but are not the common ion effect. Dilution generally increases dissolution. A catalyst has no effect on equilibrium position.

questions.question_text: The Ksp of AgCl is 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰. The molar solubility of AgCl in pure water is:
questions.explanation_correct: AgCl ⇌ Ag⁺ + Cl⁻. Let solubility = s. Then Ksp = s × s = s². s = √Ksp = √(1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) = 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰ M is Ksp itself, not the solubility. 1.8 × 10⁻⁵ M and 9.0 × 10⁻⁶ M are incorrect calculations of the square root.

questions.question_text: The Ksp expression for Ca₃(PO₄)₂ is:
questions.explanation_correct: Ca₃(PO₄)₂ ⇌ 3Ca²⁺ + 2PO₄³⁻. Ksp = [Ca²⁺]³[PO₄³⁻]². The stoichiometric coefficients become the exponents in the Ksp expression.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A swaps the exponents (2 and 3). Option C ignores coefficients entirely. Option D multiplies concentrations by coefficients instead of raising to the power.

questions.question_text: The solubility of AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) in 0.1 M NaCl solution is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: In 0.1 M NaCl, [Cl⁻] ≈ 0.1 M (common ion). Ksp = [Ag⁺][Cl⁻] = s × 0.1 = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰. s = 1.8 × 10⁻⁹ M. The common ion effect reduces solubility dramatically from 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M to 1.8 × 10⁻⁹ M.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M is the solubility in pure water, not in NaCl solution. 1.8 × 10⁻⁵ M and 1.8 × 10⁻¹¹ M are incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: The Ksp of PbCl₂ is 1.6 × 10⁻⁵. Its molar solubility in pure water is approximately:
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4.0 × 10⁻³ M incorrectly uses s² instead of 4s³. 2.5 × 10⁻² M has an arithmetic error. 1.6 × 10⁻⁵ M is Ksp itself.

questions.question_text: Will a precipitate of BaSO₄ form when 100 mL of 0.001 M BaCl₂ is mixed with 100 mL of 0.001 M Na₂SO₄? (Ksp of BaSO₄ = 1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰)
questions.explanation_correct: After mixing, total volume = 200 mL. [Ba²⁺] = 0.001 × 100/200 = 5 × 10⁻⁴ M. [SO₄²⁻] = 5 × 10⁻⁴ M. Q = [Ba²⁺][SO₄²⁻] = (5 × 10⁻⁴)² = 2.5 × 10⁻⁷. Since Q (2.5 × 10⁻⁷) >> Ksp (1.1 × 10⁻¹⁰), precipitation occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Q is much greater than Ksp, so precipitation will occur. It can be determined using the given data.

questions.question_text: Among AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰), AgBr (Ksp = 5.0 × 10⁻¹³), and AgI (Ksp = 8.5 × 10⁻¹⁷), the most soluble in water is:
questions.explanation_correct: All three salts have the same formula type (1:1), so solubility = √Ksp. The largest Ksp gives the highest solubility. AgCl has the largest Ksp (1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰), so it is the most soluble.
questions.explanation_incorrect: AgI has the smallest Ksp and is the least soluble. AgBr is intermediate. They do not have equal solubility.

questions.question_text: The equilibrium constant Kc for the reaction 2A(g) ⇌ B(g) is 4. If the initial concentration of A is 1.0 M and B is 0 M, the equilibrium concentration of B is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other values do not satisfy the equilibrium expression Kc = x/(1 − 2x)² = 4.

questions.question_text: For the endothermic reaction CaCO₃(s) ⇌ CaO(s) + CO₂(g), which change will NOT shift the equilibrium to the right?
questions.explanation_correct: CaCO₃ is a pure solid, so changing its amount does not affect the equilibrium position (its activity remains 1 as long as some solid is present). The equilibrium expression involves only CO₂.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Increasing temperature favours the endothermic direction (forward). Removing CO₂ reduces product concentration, shifting right. Decreasing pressure favours more gas moles (forward).

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the strongest acid?
questions.explanation_correct: The strength of a weak acid is indicated by its Ka value — the larger the Ka, the stronger the acid. HF has the largest Ka (3.5 × 10⁻⁴) among the options, making it the strongest acid in this group.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH₃COOH (Ka = 10⁻⁵), H₂CO₃ (Ka = 10⁻⁷), and HCN (Ka = 10⁻¹⁰) all have smaller Ka values than HF.

questions.question_text: The degree of dissociation of a 0.1 M weak acid (Ka = 1.0 × 10⁻⁴) is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a weak acid, α ≈ √(Ka/c) when α << 1. α = √(10⁻⁴/0.1) = √(10⁻³) = 0.0316 (3.16%). This means about 3.16% of the acid molecules dissociate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 0.01 uses Ka directly. 0.1 would imply 10% dissociation (too high). 0.001 underestimates the dissociation.

questions.question_text: For the reaction PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g), if Kp = Kc, then Δn must be:
questions.explanation_correct: Kp = Kc(RT)^Δn. For Kp = Kc, we need (RT)^Δn = 1, which requires Δn = 0. However, for PCl₅ ⇌ PCl₃ + Cl₂, Δn = 2 − 1 = 1 ≠ 0, so actually Kp ≠ Kc for this reaction. The question tests the general condition: Kp = Kc only when Δn = 0.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When Δn = 1, −1, or 2, (RT)^Δn ≠ 1, so Kp ≠ Kc. The condition Kp = Kc holds exclusively for Δn = 0.

questions.question_text: How does the equilibrium constant Kc differ from the reaction quotient Q in terms of the conditions under which each is defined?

options.text: Kc is calculated at equilibrium using equilibrium concentrations, while Q is calculated at any point using the current concentrations
Kc uses partial pressures while Q uses molar concentrations
Kc changes with concentration while Q changes only with temperature
There is no difference; Kc and Q always have the same numerical value

questions.explanation_correct: Kc is the value of the equilibrium expression evaluated specifically at equilibrium — it is a constant at a given temperature. Q has the same mathematical form but is evaluated at any arbitrary set of concentrations. By comparing Q with Kc, we predict the direction in which the reaction will shift.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kc and Kp both use different units, but that is a different distinction from Q. Kc depends only on temperature, not concentration. Q and Kc are equal only when the system is at equilibrium.

questions.question_text: How does the effect of increasing pressure on the equilibrium N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g) differ from its effect on the equilibrium H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g)?

options.text: Pressure increase shifts both equilibria to the right
Pressure increase shifts the first to the right (Δn = −2) but has no effect on the second (Δn = 0)
Pressure increase shifts both equilibria to the left
Pressure increase has no effect on the first but shifts the second to the right

questions.explanation_correct: For N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃, Δn = 2 − 4 = −2, so increasing pressure shifts the equilibrium towards fewer gas moles (products, right). For H₂ + I₂ ⇌ 2HI, Δn = 2 − 2 = 0, so pressure changes have no effect on the equilibrium position.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two reactions have different Δn values, so pressure affects them differently. The second reaction is unaffected because it has equal moles of gas on both sides.

questions.question_text: How does the Arrhenius definition of an acid differ from the Brønsted–Lowry definition in terms of the scope of substances classified as acids?

options.text: The Arrhenius definition is broader because it includes non-aqueous solvents
The Brønsted–Lowry definition is narrower because it requires OH⁻ production
The Brønsted–Lowry definition is broader — it includes proton donors in any solvent, while Arrhenius is limited to H⁺ production in water
Both definitions classify exactly the same set of substances as acids

questions.explanation_correct: The Arrhenius definition restricts acids to substances that produce H⁺ ions in aqueous solution. The Brønsted–Lowry definition is more general: any proton donor in any solvent (or even in the gas phase) qualifies as an acid. For example, NH₄⁺ donating a proton to NH₃ in liquid ammonia is a Brønsted–Lowry acid reaction but falls outside the Arrhenius framework.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Arrhenius is the narrower definition (water-only). Brønsted–Lowry does not require OH⁻ production; that is the Arrhenius definition of a base. The two definitions do not cover the same set of substances.

questions.question_text: How does the pH of a 0.1 M HCl solution differ from the pH of a 0.1 M CH₃COOH solution (Ka = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵) in terms of both value and the reason for the difference?

options.text: Both have pH = 1 because both are 0.1 M acid solutions
HCl has pH = 1 (fully dissociated) while CH₃COOH has pH ≈ 2.87 (partially dissociated), because HCl is a strong acid and CH₃COOH is a weak acid
HCl has pH = 1 while CH₃COOH has pH = 5, because pKa of acetic acid is approximately 5
CH₃COOH has a lower pH than HCl because weak acids produce more H⁺ over time

questions.explanation_correct: HCl is a strong acid that dissociates completely: [H⁺] = 0.1 M, so pH = 1. CH₃COOH is a weak acid: [H⁺] = √(Ka × c) = √(1.8 × 10⁻⁵ × 0.1) = √(1.8 × 10⁻⁶) ≈ 1.34 × 10⁻³ M, giving pH ≈ 2.87. The weak acid produces far fewer H⁺ ions due to partial dissociation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: At equal concentrations, a weak acid always has a higher pH (lower [H⁺]) than a strong acid. The pKa is not the pH. Weak acids do not produce more H⁺ than strong acids.

questions.question_text: How does the molar solubility of AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) differ from that of Ag₂CrO₄ (Ksp = 1.1 × 10⁻¹²) in pure water, and why can Ksp values not be directly compared to determine relative solubility for salts of different stoichiometries?

options.text: AgCl is more soluble (s = 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M) than Ag₂CrO₄ (s = 6.5 × 10⁻⁵ M) because its Ksp is larger
Ag₂CrO₄ is more soluble (s = 6.5 × 10⁻⁵ M) than AgCl (s = 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M) despite having a smaller Ksp, because its Ksp expression (4s³) relates differently to solubility than AgCl's (s²)
Both have the same molar solubility since Ksp determines solubility directly
AgCl is always more soluble than Ag₂CrO₄ regardless of stoichiometry, because it has a higher Ksp

questions.explanation_correct: For AgCl (1:1 salt): Ksp = s², so s = √(1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) = 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M. For Ag₂CrO₄ (2:1 salt): Ksp = (2s)²(s) = 4s³, so s = (Ksp/4)^(1/3) = (1.1 × 10⁻¹²/4)^(1/3) = (2.75 × 10⁻¹³)^(1/3) ≈ 6.5 × 10⁻⁵ M. Despite a smaller Ksp, Ag₂CrO₄ has a higher molar solubility because the Ksp-to-solubility relationship differs with stoichiometry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A higher Ksp does not always mean higher solubility when comparing salts of different types. The two salts have different solubilities. Ksp does not directly equal solubility.

questions.question_text: A species has an incomplete octet, carries a positive charge, and readily accepts an electron pair from a donor molecule. This species is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The three features — incomplete octet, positive charge, and ability to accept an electron pair — are hallmarks of a Lewis acid. Species like BF₃, AlCl₃, and metal cations (Fe³⁺, Cu²⁺) fit this description. A Lewis acid is defined as an electron-pair acceptor, which matches all three characteristics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A Brønsted–Lowry acid donates a proton, which is not described here. A Lewis base donates electron pairs (the opposite). An Arrhenius base releases OH⁻ in water.

questions.question_text: A solution is prepared by mixing a weak acid with pKa = 9.2 and its sodium salt in roughly equal concentrations. The pH is measured to be about 9.2. This solution can resist pH changes upon small additions of strong acid or base. This solution is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The pH of 9.2 is above 7, making the solution basic. A buffer that maintains a basic pH is called a basic buffer. Although it is made from a weak acid and its salt (which can form an acidic buffer when pKa < 7), in this case the weak acid has pKa = 9.2, meaning the acid is extremely weak and its conjugate base dominates. The result is a basic buffer with pH = pKa ≈ 9.2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An acidic buffer has pH < 7. A neutral solution has pH = 7 and does not resist pH changes. A salt hydrolysis solution does not contain a reserve of both weak acid and conjugate base in comparable amounts.

questions.question_text: A gaseous equilibrium has Δn = 0 and ΔH > 0. When the temperature is raised, the equilibrium constant increases, but when pressure is increased, the equilibrium position does not change. This equilibrium is best classified as:

options.text: An exothermic reaction sensitive to both pressure and temperature
An endothermic reaction that is pressure-insensitive but temperature-sensitive
An endothermic reaction sensitive to both pressure and temperature
An exothermic reaction that is pressure-insensitive

questions.explanation_correct: ΔH > 0 means the forward reaction is endothermic. Increasing temperature shifts an endothermic equilibrium to the right and increases K — consistent with the observation. Δn = 0 means equal moles of gas on both sides, so pressure changes do not shift the equilibrium. This is an endothermic, pressure-insensitive equilibrium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reaction is endothermic (ΔH > 0), not exothermic. It is not pressure-sensitive because Δn = 0. An exothermic reaction would have K decrease with increasing temperature.

questions.question_text: A salt dissolves in water to produce 3 moles of cations and 1 mole of anions per formula unit. Its Ksp expression takes the form Ksp = 27s⁴, where s is the molar solubility. This salt is best classified as having the stoichiometric type:
questions.explanation_correct: If the salt M₃A dissociates as M₃A ⇌ 3M⁺ + A³⁻, then [M⁺] = 3s and [A³⁻] = s. Ksp = (3s)³(s) = 27s⁴. The 3:1 cation-to-anion stoichiometry matches the description of 3 moles of cations and 1 mole of anions per formula unit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A 1:1 salt gives Ksp = s². A 1:2 salt (like CaF₂) gives Ksp = 4s³. A 2:1 salt gives Ksp = 4s³. Only a 3:1 salt yields Ksp = 27s⁴.

questions.question_text: Riya is studying the Contact process in her JEE coaching class. She learns that the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g) is exothermic with ΔH = −198 kJ. Her teacher tells her that industrially, a temperature of about 450 °C is used even though a lower temperature would give a higher yield. Riya wonders what would happen if the plant operated at only 100 °C. What is the primary reason the industry does not use a very low temperature despite the thermodynamic advantage?

options.text: The equilibrium constant becomes too small at low temperature
The rate of reaction becomes impractically slow at low temperature, even with a catalyst
The catalyst V₂O₅ does not function below 200 °C, and the reaction rate is far too low for commercial production

questions.explanation_correct: While low temperature thermodynamically favours the exothermic forward reaction, the V₂O₅ catalyst requires a minimum temperature (around 400-450 °C) to be catalytically active. Below this, the reaction rate is far too slow for commercial viability. The industry compromise is a moderate temperature that balances acceptable yield with practical reaction rate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The equilibrium constant actually increases at lower temperatures for this exothermic reaction. SO₃ does not decompose at low temperature. Option C is partially correct but incomplete — the specific limitation of the V₂O₅ catalyst is the key industrial constraint.

questions.question_text: Amit is preparing for NEET and is working on a buffer problem. He prepares a buffer by mixing 50 mL of 0.2 M CH₃COOH (pKa = 4.76) with 50 mL of 0.1 M NaOH. After the NaOH partially neutralises the acetic acid, Amit needs to calculate the pH of the resulting buffer. What is the pH of Amit's buffer solution?
questions.explanation_correct: Moles of CH₃COOH = 0.05 × 0.2 = 0.01 mol. Moles of NaOH = 0.05 × 0.1 = 0.005 mol. NaOH neutralises an equal amount of acetic acid: remaining CH₃COOH = 0.01 − 0.005 = 0.005 mol; CH₃COO⁻ formed = 0.005 mol. Using Henderson–Hasselbalch: pH = 4.76 + log(0.005/0.005) = 4.76 + 0 = 4.76.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4.46 and 5.06 would result from unequal acid/salt ratios. 7.00 is neutral pH. Since equal moles of acid and conjugate base are present, pH = pKa = 4.76.

questions.question_text: Priya is conducting a qualitative analysis experiment in her school chemistry lab. She adds dilute HCl dropwise to a solution containing Pb²⁺ ions. She observes a white precipitate of PbCl₂ forming. Her lab partner Arjun suggests heating the mixture. On heating to near boiling, the white precipitate dissolves completely. Priya is puzzled. What is the best explanation for the dissolving of PbCl₂ on heating?

options.text: HCl evaporates on heating, removing the common ion
The dissolution of PbCl₂ is endothermic, so heating increases its Ksp and molar solubility sufficiently to dissolve the precipitate
PbCl₂ decomposes into Pb and Cl₂ at high temperature
Heating converts PbCl₂ into a soluble complex PbCl₄²⁻

questions.explanation_correct: The dissolution of PbCl₂ is an endothermic process. By Le Chatelier's principle, increasing the temperature shifts the dissolution equilibrium PbCl₂(s) ⇌ Pb²⁺(aq) + 2Cl⁻(aq) to the right. The Ksp of PbCl₂ increases significantly with temperature (from ~1.6 × 10⁻⁵ at 25 °C to much higher near 100 °C), allowing the precipitate to dissolve. This is a well-known observation in qualitative analysis of Group II cations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While some HCl may evaporate, this is not the primary reason. PbCl₂ does not decompose at boiling-water temperatures. Complex formation with excess Cl⁻ does occur at very high Cl⁻ concentrations, but the primary reason for dissolution on heating is the endothermic nature of the dissolution process.

questions.question_text: Meera is studying for her Class 11 exam and sets up a thought experiment. She imagines sealing liquid water in a closed container at 25 °C. Initially the space above the water is a vacuum. Over time, she observes that the pressure above the water reaches a constant value and stops changing. Meera's teacher asks her to identify what type of equilibrium has been established. What should Meera answer?

options.text: Chemical equilibrium, because a chemical reaction has occurred
Physical equilibrium — specifically liquid–vapour equilibrium — where the rate of evaporation equals the rate of condensation
No equilibrium has been established; the water has simply stopped evaporating
Ionic equilibrium between H⁺ and OH⁻ in water

questions.explanation_correct: In a closed container, water molecules evaporate into the space above. As vapour accumulates, condensation begins. When the rate of evaporation equals the rate of condensation, a dynamic physical equilibrium is established. The pressure reaches a constant value (the equilibrium vapour pressure at 25 °C). No chemical bonds are broken or formed, so it is a physical equilibrium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No chemical reaction occurs — only a phase change. Evaporation has not stopped; both evaporation and condensation continue at equal rates. While ionic equilibrium does exist in water, that is not what causes the constant pressure above the liquid.

questions.question_text: Rohan is preparing a buffer solution for a biology experiment that requires a pH of 9.25. He has access to NH₃ (Kb = 1.8 × 10⁻⁵, pKb = 4.74) and NH₄Cl. He decides to mix equal molar quantities of NH₃ and NH₄Cl. What pH will Rohan's buffer achieve, and is it suitable for his experiment?

options.text: pH = 4.74, not suitable — he confused pKb with pKa
pH = 9.26, suitable — when [NH₃] = [NH₄⁺], pOH = pKb = 4.74, so pH = 14 − 4.74 = 9.26
pH = 7.00, not suitable — mixing a base and its salt always gives a neutral solution
pH = 14.00, not suitable — NH₃ is a strong base

questions.explanation_correct: For a basic buffer with equal concentrations of weak base (NH₃) and its conjugate acid (NH₄⁺): pOH = pKb + log([NH₄⁺]/[NH₃]) = 4.74 + log(1) = 4.74. pH = 14 − 4.74 = 9.26. This is essentially 9.25 (within rounding), making it perfectly suitable for Rohan's experiment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4.74 is the pKb, not the pH. Mixing a weak base and its salt gives a buffer, not a neutral solution. NH₃ is a weak base, not a strong base.

questions.question_text: A student lists the following factors as ones that shift the equilibrium position of a gaseous reaction. Which one does NOT actually shift the equilibrium position?

options.text: Changing the concentration of a reactant
Changing the volume of the container (when Δn ≠ 0)

questions.explanation_correct: A catalyst speeds up both the forward and reverse reactions equally. It allows the system to reach equilibrium faster but does not change the equilibrium position or the value of K. This is a common misconception among students, who often assume a catalyst 'pushes' the reaction towards products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Changing reactant concentration makes Q ≠ K, shifting equilibrium. Changing temperature changes K itself. Changing volume when Δn ≠ 0 changes partial pressures and shifts equilibrium. Only a catalyst fails to shift the equilibrium position.

questions.question_text: Which of the following aqueous solutions does NOT act as a buffer?
questions.explanation_correct: A buffer requires a weak acid/base and its conjugate. HCl is a strong acid — it dissociates completely and cannot establish the weak acid/conjugate base equilibrium needed for buffering. NaCl is the salt of a strong acid and strong base and does not provide buffering capacity. Mixing HCl + NaCl simply gives an acidic solution with no buffer action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: CH₃COOH + CH₃COONa is a classic acidic buffer. NH₃ + NH₄Cl is a basic buffer. H₂CO₃ + NaHCO₃ is a carbonate buffer. All three involve a weak acid or base with its conjugate partner.

questions.question_text: A student claims that among the following sparingly soluble salts, the one with the smallest Ksp must be the least soluble. For which pair does this reasoning actually FAIL?

options.text: Comparing AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) with AgBr (Ksp = 5.0 × 10⁻¹³) — both are 1:1 salts
Comparing AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰) with AgI (Ksp = 8.5 × 10⁻¹⁷) — both are 1:1 salts
Comparing AgCl (Ksp = 1.8 × 10⁻¹⁰, s = 1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M) with Ag₂CrO₄ (Ksp = 1.1 × 10⁻¹², s = 6.5 × 10⁻⁵ M) — different stoichiometries
Comparing AgBr (Ksp = 5.0 × 10⁻¹³) with AgI (Ksp = 8.5 × 10⁻¹⁷) — both are 1:1 salts

questions.explanation_correct: When comparing salts of the same stoichiometric type (both 1:1, or both 1:2), smaller Ksp does imply lower solubility. However, when comparing salts of different types — here AgCl (1:1, Ksp = s²) vs Ag₂CrO₄ (2:1, Ksp = 4s³) — the reasoning fails. Despite having a smaller Ksp, Ag₂CrO₄ actually has a higher molar solubility (6.5 × 10⁻⁵ M) than AgCl (1.34 × 10⁻⁵ M) because the Ksp-solubility relationship is different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D all compare salts of the same 1:1 type, where smaller Ksp correctly predicts lower solubility. The reasoning only fails when the stoichiometries differ.

questions.question_text: Why are pure solids and pure liquids excluded from the equilibrium expression, even though they participate in the reaction?

options.text: Because they do not actually take part in the reaction at the molecular level
Because their concentrations (densities) remain constant regardless of the amount present, so their activities are always unity and are absorbed into K
Because they are always present in excess and can be treated as zero
Because including them would make the equilibrium expression too complicated to solve

questions.explanation_correct: The concentration (moles per unit volume) of a pure solid or pure liquid is determined by its density and molar mass — both of which are fixed at a given temperature. Whether you have 1 g or 100 g of a pure solid, its molar concentration (density/molar mass) is the same. Because this concentration is constant, it is incorporated into the equilibrium constant by convention, leaving it out of the written expression.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Solids and liquids do participate at the molecular level (at the surface). They are not treated as zero — their activity is unity, not zero. Simplicity is not the reason; the exclusion is thermodynamically justified.

questions.question_text: Why is HF classified as a weak acid in aqueous solution despite fluorine being the most electronegative element?

options.text: Because fluorine is too small to stabilise the negative charge on F⁻
Because the H–F bond is exceptionally strong (bond energy ≈ 568 kJ/mol), making it difficult to dissociate in water despite the high polarity of the bond
Because HF forms ion pairs in solution that reduce the measured Ka
Because water cannot solvate the fluoride ion effectively

questions.explanation_correct: Although fluorine's high electronegativity makes the H–F bond highly polar (which would favour dissociation), the very short and exceptionally strong H–F bond (568 kJ/mol, the strongest single bond to hydrogen) makes it energetically costly to break. The bond strength outweighs the polarity advantage, resulting in only partial dissociation (Ka = 3.5 × 10⁻⁴). In contrast, HCl, HBr, and HI have weaker H–X bonds and are strong acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: F⁻ is actually very well solvated by water due to its high charge density. While ion pairing does occur to some extent, the primary reason is the bond strength. The small size of F⁻ actually concentrates charge and promotes strong solvation.

questions.question_text: Why does increasing temperature change the value of the equilibrium constant K, while increasing pressure (at constant temperature) does not?

options.text: Because pressure only affects gases, whereas temperature affects all states of matter
Because K is defined in terms of concentrations that change with pressure but not temperature

Because K is related to ΔG° by ΔG° = −RT ln K, and ΔG° depends on temperature (through ΔH° and ΔS°), whereas pressure changes only shift concentrations without altering the thermodynamic relationship between reactants and products
Because pressure is not a thermodynamic variable, so it cannot influence any equilibrium property

questions.explanation_correct: The equilibrium constant K is fundamentally linked to the standard Gibbs free energy change: ΔG° = −RT ln K. Since ΔG° = ΔH° − TΔS°, it is temperature-dependent, so K changes with temperature (as described by the van't Hoff equation). Pressure changes alter the concentrations/partial pressures of species, shifting the equilibrium position so that Q returns to K, but they do not change the fundamental thermodynamic relationship — hence K itself remains unchanged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pressure is a thermodynamic variable. K is defined at standard conditions; concentrations do change with pressure, but K does not. The fact that pressure affects only gases is not the fundamental reason.
